topic.title: Steps to Safely Disconnect and Handle the Electric Components
topic.shortdesc: This topic outlines the critical steps necessary to safely disconnect and handle the electric components of the motor.

section.title: Introduction
section.p: Working with electric motors requires caution and adherence to safety protocols to prevent accidents and ensure proper maintenance. Follow these steps carefully to disconnect and handle electric components safely.

li.p: Power Down: Ensure the motor is completely powered down. Turn off the main power switch and disconnect the motor from any power sources.
Lockout/Tagout: Implement the lockout/tagout procedure to ensure that the motor cannot be accidentally powered on while maintenance is being performed.
Verify Absence of Voltage: Use a voltage tester to confirm that there is no electrical energy in the motor or its components
Discharge Capacitors: Identify and discharge all capacitors within the system to eliminate the risk of electric shock from stored energy.
Use Insulated Tools: Always use tools with insulated handles rated for the appropriate voltage when working with electrical components.
Wear Protective Gear: Wear insulated gloves and safety goggles to protect yourself from potential electrical hazards.
Disconnect Wiring: Carefully disconnect all wiring from the motor. Label the wires if necessary to ensure correct reassembly.
Store Components Safely: Place all disconnected components in a safe, dry location to avoid damage and contamination.

section.title: Conclusion
section.p: Following these safety steps will help ensure that maintenance on electric motors is conducted safely and efficiently. Always adhere to manufacturer guidelines and local safety regulations.
